thread.title: 13 Women Reveal How Much They Spend on Rent
thread.title_full: 13 Women Reveal How Much They Spend on Rent

author: Sabrina Ford
title: 13 Women Reveal How Much They Spend on Rent
text:
13 Women Reveal How Much They Spend on Rent 
"I wanted roommates because it makes rent so much cheaper." Getty By Sabrina Ford Feb 21, 2017 There are so many factors to consider when finding a place to live: safety, commute time, proximity to your favorite people and places, amenities, and, of course, budget. Thirteen women with various income levels and careers tell us how much they spend on rent and what they're getting for their dollars. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 1. $1,575 for a 1-Bedroom in Manhattan Name and Age: LaToya, 30 Location: Harlem, Manhattan Occupation: Financial technical associate with a consulting business on the side Salary: $70,000, with an additional $12,000 to $14,000 a year from consulting Rent: $1,575 Apartment: 1-bedroom apartment on the fourth floor of a walk-up building Roommates: None "I don't mind paying a little more for rent if it means I'm closer to work and am able to spend just $8 on Uber Pool to get home from the office. Since my family isn't here, I like to be in an area where most of my friends live. It's nice to be in a place that's near restaurants and museums, so you can take advantage of what a city like this has to offer. But because I also want to go to brunch and travel, I have a small business as my side job." "I created my consulting business when my roommate wanted to move back home to St. Louis. I needed the extra income. I could afford my apartment by myself but not if I still wanted to save, invest, travel, shop, eat out, and see Broadway shows. I work for my clients in the morning before work, during my lunch break, in the evenings, and on weekends â€” basically, anytime I can fit it in." 2. $3,000 for a 1-Bedroom in Brooklyn Name and Age: Genevieve, 33 Location: Fort Greene, Brooklyn Occupation: Writer at a tech company Salary: $125,000 Apartment: 1-bedroom apartment in a high-rise building Roommates: None "This is more than I ever thought I'd pay in rent. I was away from New York for a while and when I was gone, I realized I like amenities, I like having someone here to accept my packages. This is just what places like this cost in New York." Getty 3. $470 to Share a 3-Bedroom in Atlanta Name and Age: Lavon, 34 Location: Atlanta Apartment: 3-bedroom, 3.5-bathroom townhouse Roommates: Two "I wanted roommates because it makes rent so much cheaper. I live in Midtown Atlanta. It's a nice area where I can get to all the different areas of the city quickly. I wanted to live in a safe neighborhood and having roommates made it possible for me to do that within my budget. It's a great value." 4. $1,670 for a 2-Bedroom in Brooklyn Name and Age: Breanna, 33 Location: Williamsburg, Brooklyn Occupation: Optician and retail manager of an eyewear shop Salary: $73,000 Apartment: Spacious 2-bedroom on the second floor of a house Roommates: None "I've been here since 2011. I've had five different roommates here and eventually I got tired of sharing the space. Once I started making more money, I decided I wanted to live here alone. Right now, I'm using the extra room as a walk-in closet. I love having a separate space to get my look together in the morning. This place has a huge kitchen and a wonderful living room. I lived in New York for a few years before I moved here but this was the first apartment that felt like home to me." Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 5. $800 to Share a 2-Bedroom in Phoenix Name and Age: Jennifer, 26 Location: Phoenix Occupation: Small business owner, event planner Salary: $60,000 Apartment: 2-bedroom, 2-bathroom townhouse Roommates: One "I could afford a nice one-bedroom in this city, but I hit the jackpot and found an amazing place and a great roommate. I'm in the best area for someone like me who wants to get out and try new foods and listen to live music. Having a roommate also allows me to save money, travel, and splurge on the things I really want." 6. $1,200 for a 1-Bedroom in Silver Springs, Maryland Name and Age: Lisa, 26 Location: Silver Springs, Maryland Occupation: Quality performance specialist at a health insurance company Salary: $70,000 Apartment: One-bedroom apartment in a high-rise building Roommates: None "My commute into Washington, D.C., is anywhere from 35 minutes to an hour, but if I lived in the city, I couldn't get what I have in this building. I love having a doorman and concierge. I want to feel safe and I like that no one can just walk up to my door. I also feel safer having a gym in the building and not going out late to the gym. I spent all this money on school to get degrees and you want to have something to show for it. It's worth it to pay a little bit more and have your own space." 7. $950 to Share a 2-Bedroom in Burbank, California Name and Age: Whitney, 33 Location: Burbank, California
